e4: While the current policy may be considered deceptive, changing to a new policy that would require investors to recalculate earnings by $0.50 might confuse some retail investors and give sophisticated hedge funds an advantage. A compromise could be to only phase out the bias for large shareholders, while still maintaining the simpler adjustment for smaller investors and informed market participants who understand the change. This approach aims to minimize disruption while promoting transparency and fairness.
e5: A reporting policy is considered ethical when it promotes transparency, consistency, and fairness. Ethical policies should clearly communicate all relevant information to stakeholders, including any material adjustments or biases that may impact financial performance or judgments. Transparency in intentions and methodologies is also crucial. In the context of this case, an ideal policy would clearly explain the rationale behind the initial bias, provide a clear transition period for investors to adjust, and be consistently applied across all public disclosures. This approach fosters trust, confidence, and understanding among stakeholders.
q9: 2011 NF35 or 2015 TB135, but 2017 EA was previously thought to be first; others are also being monitored and some pass every year, (the comets would occasionally get closer if they were actually of interstellar origin.)
